title: Win Rate TIMES Pick Rate is more important than just Win Rate
body:
http://champion.gg/champion/Thresh

Win Rate \* Play Rate = 48.96% \* 39.12% = 19.15%
So just under 1/5 of all games won in Plat+ have a {{champion:412}} in their comp.

http://champion.gg/champion/Vayne

Win Rate \* Play Rate = 51.41% \* 34.93% = 17.9%
So just over 1/6 of all games won in Plat+ have a {{champion:67}} on their team. 

Why aren't {{champion:67}} and {{champion:412}} banned more often?? 
There are other champions that also fall into this category ({{champion:40}} {{champion:92}} {{champion:103}} {{champion:222}}) that most players don't bother banning even though statistically, they should.

---------------------------------

How do we fix some of these champions?  This is debateable and can be highly controversial, but I'll just quickly give some of my own personal ideas that you can downvote me for. 

{{champion:67}} ?
Tank buster or squishy annihilator/assassin: choose one.
If you want her to be a tank buster, keep the Silver Bolts procs as-is and remove her AD steroids from her Q and R.
If you want her to be a squishy annihilator / assassin, make the silver bolt procs do flat true damage only or make it do magic damage instead.

{{champion:412}} ?
Remove the shield from his lantern. What's the point? Lantern is good for moving your allies around. It'll still be good without the shield.
Remove the passive portion from his flay. The active already has CC and damage. Why have a passive portion? Extra magic damage on ranged-autos why?

{{champion:40}} ?
I honestly think she's fine. If we really want to do anything then maybe give her tornado a smaller width / higher cooldown and reduce the knock-back of her ult? 

{{champion:103}} ?
Probably just remove the movement speed from her Q. That's all she needs, honestly. I don't think she's too bad.

{{champion:222}} ? 
I don't really have anything against her I think she's fnie. Maybe reduce the range of her Q rocket auto's. It already gives her magic damage on-hit and AOE crit/damage, why make her safer to play? 

{{champion:92}} ?
I could write a PhD thesis on changes with her.
Just some ideas:
- Remove AD scaling from her shield completely.
- Make it so she can't jump over walls with her third Q anymore (like the old days). She can already spam her Q and E on ridiculously short/non-existent cooldowns, make her have to use them to go AROUND walls so it's less obnoxious.
- Change the knock-back on her third Q to a short slow instead. It shouldn't be able to cancel channels/teleports/abilities. Hard CC on an assassin? Why? She already has a stun...
- Reduce her base movement speed. 340 on a champion with 4 dashes who also builds {{item:3044}} and {{item:3142}} ?? 
-Reduce her base AD. 56-107 is pretty good for a champion who builds full AD and gets a million AD steroids. Isn't {{champion:61}} punished with a really low base AD for having a passive that gives her magic damage on-hit? Yes, she's a different class of champion but Rito always does this. Gives some champions a really good steroid and nerfs their base stats to compensate. They didn't do this with {{champion:92}}, for some reason. 

[Honorable Mention] {{champion:39}}?
-Reduce the duration of her stun to scale from 0.5 seconds to 1.5 seconds instead of 1 to 2. 
-Hiten Style gives too much healing (her ult already heals). Reduce the healing flat damage to half the amount or make it a % lifesteal amount so building {{item:3078}} into full-tank won't allow her to heal flat 13-26 HP per hit. 
-Make the tenacity on her passive more interactive. Maybe she has tenacity against champions she's engaging. Maybe say like "reduces durations of disables from champions she's damaged with her abilities or basic attacks in the last T seconds by X%". Makes it good when she's dueling or hunting down a single champion but easier to get stopped by peeling abilities from her target's allies. Right now it's just free stats. 
 
Just some ideas off the top of my head. I haven't thought about it that hard but these were things I felt were "obvious" problematic elements. 

Let the downvoting begin...

your statistics dont take into account that two of the most popular champions are basically permabanned. Now, thresh and vayne are abnormally high, but lets take Janna and Jinx. 
1. Janna - 1% ban rate, 24% pick rate. So in the 99% of games she is available, she is picked about 24% of the time. (54% winrate)
2. Jinx - .66% ban rate, 24% pick rate. So in the 99% of games she is available, she is picked 24% of the time. (53% winrate)

Compare that to two permabanned champions - 
1. Shyvana - 68% ban rate, 10% pick rate. So in the 32% of games where she is available, she is picked 31% of the time (52% winrate)
2. Elise - 60% ban rate, 10% pick rate. So in the 40% of games she is available, she is picked 25% of the time (54% winrate)
Exactly, OP is not taking "pick or ban" champs into account. They are op but won't show up on his radar.

Here's a way to fix that.  Change the formula to find "True Pick Rate" which is their pick rate divided by their not-banned rate.
So, for the two highest banned champs, Shyvana and Elise:

Shyvana has a ban rate of 67.75, which means her not-banned rate is 32.25.  If we take 9.51 (her pick rate) divided by 32.25, we get 29.49, which is the percentage she is picked in games that she is not banned.  Then, we throw that in OP's formula, and we get 15.24%, which is still lower than Thresh and Vayne.

Elise in this formula is 13.59%...also lower.

Thresh, once we find his "True pick rate" through OP's formula is 19.49%, and Vayne is 20.37%.  So even though OP didn't take Elise and Shyvana into consideration, Thresh and Vayne are still higher.  I didn't want to run the numbers for the other ones mentioned, but feel free to.

> http://champion.gg/champion/Thresh
Win Rate \* Play Rate = 48.96% \* 39.12% = 19.15%
So just under 1/5 of all games won in Plat+ have a Thresh in their comp.

Cool, but... (100 - 48.96%) \* 39.12% = 19.97%
So just under 1/5 of all games *lost* in Plat+ *also* have a Thresh in their comp, and in fact, more losing teams have a Thresh than do winning teams. 

So if anything, this says that we should *not* be banning Thresh, because if the enemy team picks him, it statistically favors us to win. And thus, we get right back to only looking at win rates - while ensuring their pick rate is *high enough* to make win rate a valid metric. Win rate is an unreliable metric for low sample sizes, but once you have an adequately large sample, it doesn't matter how much larger you make it; the results aren't gonna change much.

This. Saying that winrate*playrate is important is very strange since playrate is a much bigger factor in that statistic than winrate (which trends to 50%). A champion can be popular and not overpowered just because people think the champion is fun e.g. Thresh. Yes he has a big kit and yes he is a great allrounder, but people have learned how to play around him and he is worse at niche jobs. He will never be as good at getting the enemy carry and locking them down as leona is. He will never be as good at grabbing as Blitzcrank is. He offers no lane sustain like Raka, Nami, Janna or Sona.

But you can make plays with him. You feel useful when you make plays. This is the greatest reason Thresh is popular.

If you plan on playong a certain champ, ban out bad matchups...

However, you used pick*win as metric to to determine who should get nerfed on your OP, while it does a even worse job for that than winrate alone...

This is cool stuff!

One of the things I think we fall short on is having a shared understanding of metrics that indicate a champion's or item's power level. Because Win Rate is so easily accessed and intuitive, it's something that players (developers included) default to as the first place they look to to determine power. This is probably as good a start as any other, but stopping there leaves much to be desired. As you have demonstrated, simply adding in a contribution for play rate can tell a much different story about what is powerful.

Something challenging with data like this is that, as you add in more contributing factors, figuring out or remembering what they mean becomes less intuitive. Thankfully, you continually reminded us how to read the info you provided with the "X game in plat+ are won by Y champ."

I'm somewhat curious as to how many players prefer to let data drive their pick and ban decisions vs how many prefer to just play and ban what they personally think is strongest.

Highlighting the importance of pick rate in terms of win rate is always good, but the proposed changes would make most of those champions unplayable.

Vayne especially is very high risk for very high reward, so nerfing her is almost synonymous with removing her (the way they did with Morde at the end of Season 1). Same with champs like Lee Sin, Riven, and Thresh. The power of these champions is not expressed solely through their kit, but the player, because these tend to be MUCH more mechanically demanding to play at a high level than say, Orianna, Ahri, Garen, or Annie.

The bottom line is that pick/win rates can be used as an indicator for when a champion is strong, but these ones fall well within the parameters of normalcy (45-55% win rate). When you want to talk about pick and win rates, you can't just multiply them and get a meaningful number, because they express different things.

Win rate = how strong the champion is + **how well people can play it** (this second part is EXTREMELY important in these discussions)
Pick rate = how popular the champion is (and can indicate/reflect their perceived power or enjoyability to play)

Just from this you can see how merely multiplying them not only obfuscates the issue, but detracts from what the numbers really mean. Beyond that, such an equation doesn't account for other variables like team composition, player warding habits, and team cohesion. It also doesn't account for afks/leavers which contribute to losses marked against those champions (and often against popular ones).

There is no way to interpret these numbers in a basic form. There is simply too much involved with it. Calling for nerfs because, "Teams with X champion win Y% of the time" simply doesn't make sense.

It also doesn't account for afks/leavers which contribute to losses marked against those champions (and often against popular ones).

It doesn't because when you are banning, no champions have been picked. Again, like I've been stressing: **you have little to no information** the pick and win rates simply provide a general average across ALL games of a certain elo. 

> There is no way to interpret these numbers in a basic form. There is simply too much involved with it. Calling for nerfs because, "Teams with X champion win Y% of the time" simply doesn't make sense.

Most people call for nerfs when they have a frustrating experience playing against a champion ({{champion:429}} {{champion:105}}{{champion:92}} ) or happen to lose a lot against a champion that shows up all the time ({{champion:67}} {{champion:39}} {{champion:92}})

Moral of the story? Nerf {{champion:92}}  :^)

Neither of those are really reasons to nerf in most cases, despite people calling for them. A lot of people call for nerfs when they lose against something instead of learning how to deal with and defeat it. For example, Ahri and Fizz are common examples of "frustrating" to play against, but if you take the time to learn how to play them yourself, you find out how they work, what their weaknesses are, how you might exploit those weaknesses, and how to bait a player into making a bad decision. Yet so many people on these boards don't do any of that. Worse, you see this at all elo of play, yet you have some arrogant pricks on here acting as if their rank makes them an exception.

Nerfs are hard to justify in most cases, because most champions have already been nerfed down to a point where they border on playability. Crossing this border is why Morde is getting a rework now after 4 years of being mostly ignored--he was nerfed into the ground. This is not a healthy game policy, and it is no way to respect your players and the champions they want to play.
If you are first pick and are picking something that is hard countered, you ban those counters.  After that you ban those annoying champs you hate dealing with.

As someone who plays primarily top and jungle, my list is generally Elise, Kayle, Master Yi, Xin Zhao, Yasuo, Shyvana. For me, and I think a lot of players, it's a bit of both. 

If I'm first pick and want to go Ahri mid or Soraka support I'll ban what i think does best against them. Other times I'll simply look at op.gg's stats on bans and choose from the list.

While i agree that winrate isolated is a bad indicator, winrate times pickrate isn't much better.

So thresh is part of 19.15% off all winning teams? Well, 19.97% off all loosing comps have a thresh in them... so in the end, it doesn't show us much other than winrate does...
iT's a even worse indicator for champion power actually, cause while pickrate is a factor in some way, it doesn't say as much over the actuall power level than winrate while it's a bigger factor i your math as pickrates differ far more than winrates.
A champion with 10% pickrate and 100% winrate would be less powerfull than a champ with a 80%pickrate and 20% winrate by your approach...

Winrate is the defining factor for power, however it usually is biased by many other factors, so it has to be seen in conjunktion with thos other influences.

Pickrate is a factor, mostly in that high pickrate correlates to lowers winrate and low pickrate increases winrate compared to what should be by raw power of the champ.
A low pickrate champ usually does better cuase his enemies probably never face him and have no experience in that matchup.
Chances are also that low pickrate champs fill a very specific niche and thus usually get used as counter picks vs certain strats/picks, which means they are mosly played in an enviroment they thrive in.

High pickrate champs how ever are well know, everyone probably has played vs thresh a couple of times and knows the matchup(probably also played **as** thresh, which helps even more at playing vs him)
They also oftern get picked regardless of counterpicks, so they run into bad matchups for the sake of playing the FotM.

Also, as ChaoticPinecone explained, you have to see pickrate in corelation to ban rate.
 
Another important factot is winrate in comparison to player games with that champ, cause else high skill floor/cap champs would apear weak.
Compareing winrates atr 125+games, so the winrates of mains does show how well those champions perform if used to their max potential(though still biased by pick-reate realted matchup experience, counterpicks etc)
This however hets influenced by counterpicks. 'Mains' often pick their champ regardless off the matchup, so it can happen that mains have a worse winrate than people with less games on that champ.
Sona for example has 53.2% win for players with 5-15 sona-games, but only a 52.2 winrate for players with 125+ sona games.
This ofc also means winrates should be seperated for differnt elos, as their might be a difference in the skill required to play compared to the skill required to play against, leading to different winrates in different elos.

Another factor is how team-reliant a champ is, so in which style of teamcomp he works best.
For example: Champions that are strong in pickcomps for usually have a worse performance in soloQ than in competetive 5v5, as pick comps need a high level off coordination than death-ball or siege comps.

Winrate based on gamelength compared to average gamelength is a factor aswell
If all champions that have a high lategame winrate have a overall low winrate, maybe it is to hard to reach lategame.
If all champs that have a strong lategame have a overall high winrate, maybe it's to hard to abuse a weak early and finish befor late(or the earlygame of all of them is to strong compared to their lategame power)

The one problem with your analysis:

The pickrate and winrate for highly banned champions. For example, {{champion:102}} boasts a 68% ban rate in Plat+ games, and is still picked around 10% of the time. That means in the 32% of games she is available, she is picked about 1/3 of the time. If we extend this statistic to all games if she was never banned, she SHOULD have a 30% pick rate with a 52% winrate, edging out all champions except Thresh and Vayne. Basically, yes.

Let A = Sona was picked on the team.
Let B = Team wins

Win rate of a champion is defined as proportion of times a team wins given that champion is on the team. If we say that {{champion:37}} has a 52.33% win rate, that means that a team has a 52.33% win rate given that Sona is on it. Aka we say Sona's Win rate is P( B | A ) = 52.33%

The chance that a team wins AND it has a {{champion:37}} on it is P( A & B ) which can be computed by P( B | A ) \* P( A ) which is a champion's win rate TIMES their pick rate. 

Therefore, if you ban {{champion:37}} in champion select then you're banning against the 2% chance that {{champion:37}} is picked and ALSO wins.

I feel there's a significant flaw in your method - you aren't accounting for a champion's games lost. Let's examine your Thresh example - sure 19.15% of winning teams include a Thresh, but 19.97% of losing teams have one (51.04% loss rate.) More teams with Thresh lose than win. Why should you ban a champion that statistically will more likely lose than win? And Thresh is not alone in having a losing record among high pick-rate champions - as per champion.gg, seven of the top twenty most-picked champions have losing records.

Which is not to say that pick rate isn't important, since if you ban a champion nobody was going to play anyways it's effectively a wasted ban. For example, despite his high winrate of 53.48%, you probably shouldn't ban Galio because he is only picked in 0.39% of games - most likely nobody is going to play him in your game anyways.

The answer to "who should I ban?" is always going to be more complicated than any simple metric, and the one you're suggesting has serious flaws.
